Summary: Sighting of abnormal lights appearing in cloud bank off of Atlantic coast.
divs: sighting detailswhen visiting in new bern 2 years ago, shortly before moving here to havelock, a friend and i decided to drive to atlantic beach shortly after midnight. when we left new bern, the skies were clear, but by the time we had reached the beach there was a storm coming in over the atlantic. we walked down to just above the wave line, and my friend sat down to play his guitar. i remained standing, and was photographing him and the surrounding area as he played. as the storm moved closer, i turned to watch it approach. i did see the usual lightning flashes inside the cloud bank (i grew up on the gulf coast, and am familiar with offshore storms and what they can look like at night). however, and what i am contacting you about, what i also saw, and what i'm curious about, is an apparently straight line of flashing colored lights within the cloud bank. i am uncertain as to the size of the lights, as they were diffused through the cloud bank, and for the same reason i have no idea how far offshore they might have been (and that's a tricky estimate against the water and at night, at best), but they appeared to be at approximately 35 to 40 degrees above the horizon (if i were standing in the same spot, i could point to pretty much exactly the height they appeared to me), and to cover an area...well...if i were the apex of a triangle, and the lights on the ends were the other corners, my arms would be stretched out about 30 degrees as well, if that makes sense. the lights were, in order, red, blue, green, and yellow, and flashed in no particular order, although i watched them for a good 19 minutes, as did my companion. there was no noticable sound other than the storm itself. i know this was not an aircraft. my father was a pilot and a flight instructor for nearly 40 years, and i grew up at airports and in planes, and have observed them in all weather conditions. although the red and green lights might have belonged to known aircraft, the blue light was very intense and almost electric\cobalt, not a distortion of a white strobe light, and the yellow at the far end has nothing to do with anything known to me. the red was equally intense, and definitely not "pink lightning." have seen that, also, during a blizzard. i remember thinking, "oh how lovely!" as i watched the lights flash. i never felt uneasy, and the lights appeared to stay at the same distance, at least their size and position never changed appreciably. the storm itself did continue to move in, and when the rain started, my companion and i left and went back to the car. we were, at the time, more interested in discussing the very odd music that he was inspired to play than in the lights. it was only later that i even began to wonder about them at all. is this colored lightning possibly natural phenomina? although i grew up on the gulf coast after the age of 5, i know precious little about atlantic storms and what they might do. the fact that the lights were in such a straight line, and that the colors never changed places leads me to doubt it, but still...
